results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set authentication: anonymous: enabled to
false.
If using executable arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
--anonymous-auth=false
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the anonymous-auth argument is set to false (Automated)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set authorization: mode to Webhook. If
using executable arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_AUTHZ_ARGS variable.
--authorization-mode=Webhook
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --authorization-mode argument is not set to AlwaysAllow (Automated)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set authentication: x509: clientCAFile to
the location of the client CA file.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_AUTHZ_ARGS variable.
--client-ca-file=<path/to/client-ca-file>
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --client-ca-file argument is set as appropriate (Automated)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set readOnlyPort to 0.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
--read-only-port=0
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --read-only-port argument is set to 0 (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set streamingConnectionIdleTimeout to a
value other than 0.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
--streaming-connection-idle-timeout=5m
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --streaming-connection-idle-timeout argument is not set to 0 (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set protectKernelDefaults: true.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
--protect-kernel-defaults=true
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --protect-kernel-defaults argument is set to true (Automated)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set makeIPTablesUtilChains: true.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
remove the --make-iptables-util-chains argument from the
KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --make-iptables-util-chains argument is set to true (Automated)

results.remediation:
Edit the kubelet service file /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf
on each worker node and remove the --hostname-override argument from the
KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --hostname-override argument is not set (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set eventRecordQPS: to an appropriate level.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameter in KUBELET_SYSTEM_PODS_ARGS variable.
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --event-qps argument is set to 0 or a level which ensures appropriate event capture (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set tlsCertFile to the location
of the certificate file to use to identify this Kubelet, and tlsPrivateKeyFile
to the location of the corresponding private key file.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the below parameters in KUBELET_CERTIFICATE_ARGS variable.
--tls-cert-file=<path/to/tls-certificate-file>
--tls-private-key-file=<path/to/tls-key-file>
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --tls-cert-file and --tls-private-key-file arguments are set as appropriate (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to add the line rotateCertificates: true or
remove it altogether to use the default value.
If using command line arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
remove --rotate-certificates=false argument from the KUBELET_CERTIFICATE_ARGS
variable.
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the --rotate-certificates argument is not set to false (Manual)

results.remediation:
Edit the kubelet service file /etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf
on each worker node and set the below parameter in KUBELET_CERTIFICATE_ARGS variable.
--feature-gates=RotateKubeletServerCertificate=true
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Verify that the RotateKubeletServerCertificate argument is set to true (Manual)

results.remediation:
If using a Kubelet config file, edit the file to set TLSCipherSuites: to
TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
or to a subset of these values.
If using executable arguments, edit the kubelet service file
/etc/systemd/system/kubelet.service.d/10-kubeadm.conf on each worker node and
set the --tls-cipher-suites parameter as follows, or to a subset of these values.
--tls-cipher-suites=TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_ECDHE_RSA_WITH_CHACHA20_POLY1305,TLS_ECDHE_ECDSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_256_GCM_SHA384,TLS_RSA_WITH_AES_128_GCM_SHA256
Based on your system, restart the kubelet service. For example:
systemctl daemon-reload
systemctl restart kubelet.service
results.test_desc: Ensure that the Kubelet only makes use of Strong Cryptographic Ciphers (Manual)

results.remediation:
Identify all clusterrolebindings to the cluster-admin role. Check if they are used and
if they need this role or if they could use a role with fewer privileges.
Where possible, first bind users to a lower privileged role and then remove the
clusterrolebinding to the cluster-admin role :
kubectl delete clusterrolebinding [name]
results.test_desc: Ensure that the cluster-admin role is only used where required (Manual)

results.remediation: Where possible, remove get, list and watch access to secret objects in the cluster.
results.test_desc: Minimize access to secrets (Manual)

results.remediation:
Where possible replace any use of wildcards in clusterroles and roles with specific
objects or actions.
results.test_desc: Minimize wildcard use in Roles and ClusterRoles (Manual)

results.remediation: Where possible, remove create access to pod objects in the cluster.
results.test_desc: Minimize access to create pods (Manual)

results.remediation:
Create explicit service accounts wherever a Kubernetes workload requires specific access
to the Kubernetes API server.
Modify the configuration of each default service account to include this value
automountServiceAccountToken: false
results.test_desc: Ensure that default service accounts are not actively used. (Manual)

results.remediation:
Modify the definition of pods and service accounts which do not need to mount service
account tokens to disable it.
results.test_desc: Ensure that Service Account Tokens are only mounted where necessary (Manual)

results.remediation: Remove the system:masters group from all users in the cluster.
results.test_desc: Avoid use of system:masters group (Manual)

results.remediation: Where possible, remove the impersonate, bind and escalate rights from subjects.
results.test_desc: Limit use of the Bind, Impersonate and Escalate permissions in the Kubernetes cluster (Manual)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that
the .spec.privileged field is omitted or set to false.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of privileged containers (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.hostPID field is omitted or set to false.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host process ID namespace (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.hostIPC field is omitted or set to false.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host IPC namespace (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.hostNetwork field is omitted or set to false.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers wishing to share the host network namespace (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.allowPrivilegeEscalation field is omitted or set to false.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers with allowPrivilegeEscalation (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.runAsUser.rule is set to either MustRunAsNonRoot or MustRunAs with the range of
UIDs not including 0.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of root containers (Automated)

results.remediation:
Create a PSP as described in the Kubernetes documentation, ensuring that the
.spec.requiredDropCapabilities is set to include either NET_RAW or ALL.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers with the NET_RAW capability (Automated)

results.remediation:
Ensure that allowedCapabilities is not present in PSPs for the cluster unless
it is set to an empty array.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers with added capabilities (Automated)

results.remediation:
Review the use of capabilites in applications running on your cluster. Where a namespace
contains applicaions which do not require any Linux capabities to operate consider adding
a PSP which forbids the admission of containers which do not drop all capabilities.
results.test_desc: Minimize the admission of containers with capabilities assigned (Manual)

results.remediation:
If the CNI plugin in use does not support network policies, consideration should be given to
making use of a different plugin, or finding an alternate mechanism for restricting traffic
in the Kubernetes cluster.
results.test_desc: Ensure that the CNI in use supports Network Policies (Manual)

results.remediation: Follow the documentation and create NetworkPolicy objects as you need them.
results.test_desc: Ensure that all Namespaces have Network Policies defined (Manual)

results.remediation:
if possible, rewrite application code to read secrets from mounted secret files, rather than
from environment variables.
results.test_desc: Prefer using secrets as files over secrets as environment variables (Manual)

results.remediation:
Refer to the secrets management options offered by your cloud provider or a third-party
secrets management solution.
results.test_desc: Consider external secret storage (Manual)

results.remediation: Follow the Kubernetes documentation and setup image provenance.
results.test_desc: Configure Image Provenance using ImagePolicyWebhook admission controller (Manual)

results.remediation:
Follow the documentation and create namespaces for objects in your deployment as you need
them.
results.test_desc: Create administrative boundaries between resources using namespaces (Manual)

results.remediation:
Use security context to enable the docker/default seccomp profile in your pod definitions.
An example is as below:
  securityContext:
    seccompProfile:
      type: RuntimeDefault
results.test_desc: Ensure that the seccomp profile is set to docker/default in your pod definitions (Manual)

results.remediation:
Follow the Kubernetes documentation and apply security contexts to your pods. For a
suggested list of security contexts, you may refer to the CIS Security Benchmark for Docker
Containers.
results.test_desc: Apply Security Context to Your Pods and Containers (Manual)

results.remediation:
Ensure that namespaces are created to allow for appropriate segregation of Kubernetes
resources and that all new resources are created in a specific namespace.
results.test_desc: The default namespace should not be used (Manual)
